text: Privilege: Non-Allocation of Time to Speak in Parliament [Col. 1579] Special Security Arrangements on 17th February, 2025 [Col. 1579] ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS [Cols. 1582-1637] ISSUES FACED BY YOUTH MIGRATED TO RUSSIA SEEKING EMPLOYMENT:
Statement by Minister of Foreign Affairs, Foreign Employment and Tourism [Col. 1641] HYDRATED LIME IMPORTED FOR WATER PURIFICATION:
Statement by Minister of Urban Development, Construction and Housing [Col. 1643] PRIVATE MEMBERS MOTIONS:
Acquisition of Estate Roads to the Government [Cols.16521671] Preparation of A Proper Procurement Programme for the Process of Purchasing Goods for Co-operatives

[Cols. 1672-1687] Making Arrangements for Maintaining A Rice Reserve with the Government [Cols. 16871705] Formulation of A Proper Methodology for the Appointment of Labour Welfare Officers [Cols.1706-1722] Abolishing the Pension Scheme of the Members of Parliament of Sri Lanka [Cols.1723-1742] Appointing A Select Committee of Parliament to Investigate and Make Appropriate Recommendations Regarding
the Cremation, Instead of Burial of the COVID-19 Pandemic Victims [Cols.1742-1760] ADJOURNMENT MOTION: Proper Programme to Develop and Free Cricket from Fraud and Corruption [Cols. 17601770]
The Parliament met at 9.30 a.m., MR. DEPUTY SPEAKER [THE HON. (DR.) RIZVIE SALIH]
PRIVILEGE: NON-ALLOCATION OF TIME TO SPEAK IN

( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) A Motion may be moved to refer the Question of Privilege raised by the Hon. (Dr.) Ramanathan Archchuna, M.P., in Parliament on 23rd January, 2025 to the Committee on Ethics and Privileges.

( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) I wish to inform all the Hon. Members of Parliament that the following special security arrangements will be implemented in connection with the Budget Speech for the year 2025 to be made by the Hon. Minister of Finance on Monday, the 17th of February, 2025:
I wish to inform that the security arrangements for Friday, the 14th of February, 2025 will be as follows:
The entire Parliament building including the rest rooms and wardrobes of the Members of Parliament will be subjected to security inspection on this day.
I also wish to inform that the security arrangements for Monday, the 17th of February, 2025 will be as follows:
(a) The High Security Areas/Significant Locations identified in the Parliament building will be subjected to security inspection on this day.
(b) The Public Gallery will be open to the invited guests only.
(c) The Hon. Members of Parliament accompanying their spouses may alight at the staff entrance and proceed to the Parliament building.
(d) The Hon. Members are kindly requested to be driven by chauffeurs, if possible, and to refrain from bringing guests to Parliament on this day.

(e) Parliamentary staff drivers will be stationed at the Members' Entrance, Staff Entrance and Public Entrance to park the vehicles driven by Hon. Members of Parliament in the designated parking areas.

(f) Since the Public Gallery is restricted to invited guests, all the Hon. Members of Parliament are kindly requested to have any other guests (excluding spouses) alight at the Jayanthipura Entrance. A special transport arrangement has been made to take these guests to the Public Entrance.
(g) The MPP Car Park will be kept closed on this day and the vehicles of the MPP will be directed to the relevant car parks.
(h) Special traffic arrangements will be adopted by the Traffic Police and the nearest police stations in the area on this day.
Cooperation of all Hon. Members of Parliament is kindly expected towards the aforementioned special security arrangements.

CEYLON ELECTRICITY BOARD: EMPLOYEES ON CASUAL/
() , ? asked the Minister of Energy: (a) Will he inform this House -
(i) the number of those employed at the Ceylon Electricity Board, separately on permanent, contract and casual basis;
(ii) the amounts that were paid to these workers as salaries, allowances and bonuses from 2015 up to now, separately in respect of each year;
(iii) whether he accepts that tasks such as installing electricity lines, digging pits and disconnecting power have been outsourced to contracting institutions;
(iv) the amounts that were paid to such institutions from 2015 up to now, separately in respect of each year;

(v) the reasons for outsourcing the works referred to in (iii) above to contracting institutions in a backdrop where excess numbers of workers receiving high salaries, allowances and bonuses are employed at the Ceylon Electricity Board; and
(vi) the measures to be taken to rectify this situation?

Hon. Deputy Minister, you may provide the Answer to the Question raised by the Hon. Kins Nelson.

( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) May I make an announcement. We have had a very unfortunate situation here. I would like to remind the Hon. Members of both sides of the House, whichever party they may belong to, the Government or the Opposition, that the masses wanted a change; they wanted a change in the culture of Parliament. Shall we all provide what the masses wanted? There is a mandate that the masses have given us. So, let us live up to it. I think we all should resolve to live up to that and provide a different environment in this Parliament. Thank you very much.
Next, Question No. 6 - 151/2024 - (1), the Hon. Ajith P. Perera. - [Not in the Chamber.]
NATIONAL SAVINGS BANK: FINANCIAL STATUS AND
asked the Minister of Finance, Planning and Economic Development:
(i) the date of incorporation of the National Savings Bank;
(ii) the names of the present Chairman, Directors of the Board and the CEO;
(iii) the number of branches and employees;
(iv) the paid-up capital, as of today;
(v) whether is it in compliance with BASEL requirement of capital adequacy; and
(vi) the steps taken to address non-compliance, if any?
(b) Will he also inform this House, separately, the -
(i) profit for the last 10 years and expected profit for the next three years;
(ii) return on investment for the last 10 years as per (i) above ;
(iii) administration cost and lending margin rate for the last five years;
(iv) administration cost as a percentage of lending rate; and;
(v) balance sheet values from 2019 to date?
(c) Will he further inform this House -
(i) whether loans over Rs. 1 billion were written off;
(ii) the names of the entities involved; and
(iii) legal procedures adopted for the write-offs?

( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Question No. 8 - 246/2024 - (1), the Hon. S.M. Marikkar. - [Not in the Chamber.]
FOLK ARTS CENTRE IN KAIKAWALA: CURRENT STATUS
asked the Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) whether he is aware that the Folk Arts Centre - Jana Kala Kendraya - established in Kaikawala, Bentara has been abandoned without being used at present; (ii) whether that Folk Arts Centre is still in usable condition; (iii) or else, whether that can be reused after renovation; and (iv) the steps that will be taken to restore its administrative functions?
) ) ( () - , ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Hiniduma Sunil Senevi - Minister of Buddhasasana, Religious and Cultural Affairs) ,

BURIAL OF COVID-19 VICTIMS IN MAJMA NAGAR: ARMED

(i) whether he is aware that the remains of the persons who died of COVID-19 pandemic were buried in Majma Nagar area in Batticaloa on a policy decision of the Government and the assistance and contribution of the three forces were obtained for this purpose;
(ii) the number of staff officers and other ranks included in the subdivision detailed for such burial activities, separately;
(iii) the amounts paid as allowances to those officers in addition to the basic salary;
(iv) the number of vehicles of the three forces and the number of vehicles obtained on rent basis for the use in burial activities;
(v) the amount of money borne as expenditure for fuel for each such vehicle;
(vi) whether the relatives of the deceased person were charged fees for burial activities; and if so, the amount so charged, separately?
) ) ( () - ) (The Hon. Major General (Rtd.) Aruna Jayasekera - Deputy Minister of Defence) , :
( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) Hon. Deputy Speaker,
: , : : : : ; , : , , : : : Sir, Operative Paragraph 8 of the Geneva Resolution against Sri Lanka adopted by the Human Rights Council on the 23rd of March, 2021 states this, I quote:

"Expresses further concern that the response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has had an impact on freedom of religion or belief and exacerbated the prevailing marginalization of and discrimination against the Muslim community, and that cremations for those deceased from COVID-19 have prevented Muslims and members of other religions from practising their own burial religious rites, and has disproportionately affected religious minorities and exacerbated distress and tensions;"
Hon. Minister, another matter arising from this situation was the other unscientific decision taken to bury COVID-19 victims in a faraway place in Oddamavadi. :,
Geneva Resolution Operative Paragraph 9 Human Rights Council
"Calls upon the Government of Sri Lanka to ensure the prompt, thorough and impartial investigation and, if warranted, prosecution of all alleged crimes relating to human rights violations ...."
So, the Resolution is calling upon the Government to have an inquiry and punish the people concerned.

But, what does this Government do? It appoints the then Director General of Health Services as the Secretary of the current Ministry of Health and Dr. Hasitha Tissera, who had also been part of that Expert Committee and was also responsible for the decisions, as Acting Chief Epidemiologist. No inquiry has been conducted, whereas the Human Rights Council has specifically asked the Government to conduct inquiries and punish these individuals for having violated the human rights of the

religious minorities. So, will the Government take action against those individuals who were responsible for taking these unscientific decisions, religiously profiling a communitys conduct and denying them their religious freedom in such a fashion?

) ) ( () - ) (The Hon. Major General (Rtd.) Aruna Jayasekera - Deputy Minister of Defence) Hon. Member, your Supplementary Question is very clear. Your comments and inputs have been taken. Let me buy some time and refer this matter to the consultative authorities and then come back to you in due course.

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) Sir, my second Supplementary Question is this. ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Hon. Member, could you please make it brief because we have the Private Members' Motions to be taken up? And, we are already running short of time. Thank you very much.
( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) Yes, Hon. Deputy Speaker, I will be very brief.

This particular incident cannot be just brushed aside. I know that you all, including the Hon. Leader of the House, sometimes get annoyed when I raise these questions repeatedly over an issue like this. But, this is a matter that has gained international attention regarding human rights in this country. A particular religious community has been affected seriously, not only the Muslims but also the Catholics who believe in burial. This burial decision had also been taken in an unscientific manner, wasting public funds and taking burials to a faraway place. And also, the Government at that time wanted to take the bodies to the Maldives!
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Hon. Member, could you please come to the second Supplementary Question?

( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) Also, Sir, the then President contacted the President of the Maldives wanting to send our "Janazahs" to the Maldives for burial! Such stupid decisions were made by the then administration and some stupid officials, who are now holding responsible positions in Government, have gone unpunished. At least, an administrative inquiry has to be conducted against them. That is what we are asking for and will the Government take action in that regard?

) ( () ) (The Hon. Major General (Rtd.) Aruna Jayasekera) Hon. Deputy Speaker, I have to say the same thing again: I will consult the Hon. Minister and the other responsible authorities and come back to you in due course because this question is very sensitive in nature, as you understand and you all are aware. I will certainly come back to you. Thank you.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Okay. Now, the second round of the Questions for Oral Answers.
Question No. 6 - 151/2024, the Hon. Ajith P. Perera
: SOLAR POWER ADDED TO THE NATIONAL GRID: DETAILS
) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunathilleka on behalf of the Hon.
(a) Will he inform this House the - (i) solar power capacity that has been added to the National Grid of Sri Lanka;
(ii) annual volume of solar power added to the National Grid of Sri Lanka;
(iii) date on which the Soorya Bala Sangramaya (Solar Power Campaign) Project was launched;

(iv) volume of solar power that has been added to the National Grid under the Net Plus, Net Metering and Net Accounting methods introduced by the Soorya Bala Sangramaya (Solar Power Campaign) Project, separately; and
(v) actions that will be taken to promote solar power?
4. - Net Plus, Net Plus Plus, Net Accounting, Net Metering -
7. : 20 - 300-400MW - - Energy Storage Systems - - Battery Energy Storage Systems - - Pumped Hydro Storage Power Plants - : :, : - system stability - (: , ) :
) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunathilleka on behalf of the Hon.
() , ? asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Education, Higher Education and Vocational Education:
(i) whether she is aware that no National School is situated within the Colombo North Education Division, out of those education divisions in the Colombo District;
(ii) in such case, whether she will take action to establish a National School within the Colombo North Education Division in time to come;
(iii) whether a suitable school has been identified for this purpose; and
(iv) if not, whether a suitable school will be selected for it in the time to come?
() : ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Next, Ministerial Statements.
.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) Hon. Deputy Speaker, -
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Yes, Hon. Ponnambalam?
.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) Thank you, Hon. Deputy Speaker.

Sir, I do not normally speak out of turn. But, since the Hon. Prime Minister is present here, I wish to seek a clarification and an answer, if possible, with regard to something that is of significant public concern. Hon. Prime Minister, I am pretty sure that you are aware that Mr. Lasantha Wickrematunge's daughter has written a letter to you. I have a copy of that letter and it is quite a damning letter. It calls for the Impeachment of the Attorney-General for gross abuse of power and gross neglect of duty. It is a four-page letter and the matters she raises in it are actually quite shocking. I think your Government has repeatedly come on record saying that the Attorney-Generals Department is an independent institution and that there should be no interference with regard to decisions being made by it. But here, when a victims family is actually casting aspersions on the very Head of that institution, with regard to that individuals conduct, I think it is a very important instance where the Government must in some way intervene. Since this letter is addressed to you and also copied to the Minister of Justice and National Integration, I wish to find out whether the Hon. Prime Minister has something in mind with regard to this matter. Thank you very much.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Hon. Prime Minister, if you want to respond to that, you can.
) ( () () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) (Ms.) Harini Amarasuriya) Thank you, Hon. Deputy Speaker.
Yes, Hon. Member, I have received the letter and I am planning to respond to that letter, to Ms. Wickrematunge, personally since she has sent it to me.

Our Governments position on this case is very clear. We intend to seek justice for the murder of Lasantha Wickrematunge. That has been our position in the past and that continues to be our position currently as well. I well understand Ahimsas concerns and the agony she must be feeling right now. But, I want to assure her that we will do everything in our power to make sure that justice is delivered on this matter. As you know, we are doing our very best to follow due process to give the Attorney-Generals Department that independence. But, justice has to be served. That is also the responsibility of our Government, to ensure that justice is served.

We have had extensive discussions. The President met with those involved with the investigations to try and see what could be done. If necessary, we will initiate new inquiries and take every step possible to gather new evidence, if the question is about lack of evidence. But, this is a case which has plenty of evidence. There have been many people involved with the inquiries, who have worked hard on this case. If necessary, we will file a new case. We will do everything we can to make sure that this case receives justice and that Ahimsas concerns are addressed. Thank you.
( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) Hon. Deputy Speaker, may I intervene?
.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) Hon. Deputy Speaker, I have just one more matter. ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) First, shall we finish with the Hon. Ponnambalam's matter?

.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) Hon. Prime Minister, your comments today are quite reassuring. You know that the Wickrematunge family have been very uncompromising with regard to their pursuit of justice. But, at the same time, they have been extremely measured with their public statements with regard to the investigations into Mr. Lasantha

Wickrematunges death. His daughter's coming on record requesting for an Impeachment of the Attroney-General, you would agree, is quite a significant request and I think the response from the Government must be equally significant because this is an emblematic case. And the second point is, Mr. Wickrematunge is iconic. You know that a very few journalists would demand and command the amount of respect that he did across the Floor of this House and even across the ethnic lines.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Hon. Ponnambalam, could you keep that very brief? We have to manage the time.
.. ( .. ) (The Hon. G.G. Ponnambalam) So, I think it is extremely encouraging what you said, Hon. Prime Minister, and I sincerely hope that you would take those steps very urgently.
( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) Hon. Deputy Speaker, before the Prime Minister answers, let me intervene.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Hon. Rauff Hakeem., could you be very brief bcause we have to move on to the Private Members' Motions.
( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem, Attorney-at-Law) I will be brief, Sir.

Hon. Prime Minister, thank you very much for your response; we are being reassured in some way. But, yet, when I see the newspapers, the response by the Attorney-Generals Department, as it has been reported, relates to a very puerile argument relating to a lapse in the identification parade of the suspects and that that prompted the proceeding with the nolle prosequi, withdrawing of indictment or charge sheet against the so-called suspects. It is a very, very funny thing.

Your own Government, in your Manifesto and in your election propaganda, made it very clear that you would establish an independent Prosecutors Office instead of the Attorney-General handling these matters directly. Therefore, with this new matter coming up, we feel that the prosecutorial discretion of the Attorney-Generals Department is being used willy-nilly to free selected people for other political purposes and other extraneous reasons. I am sorry to say that. Our Attorney-Generals Department has very high-ranking, good and very conscientious officers. It is being hampered by a serious lack of personnel and you have to recruit more officers. Those issues are there, but this type of lapse regarding a high-profile case of this nature is a very serious matter. Therefore, on behalf of the Opposition, I now

give notice, provided that the Committee on Parliamentary Business - we are not a part of that Committee - agree, that we want a full-day debate on this particular issue so that this matter should be fully thrashed out and it should never recur. Thank you.
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Okay, Hon. Rauf Hakeem, I think you have made yourself clear.

( ) (The Hon. Kaveenthiran Kodeeswaran) . . rose. ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Hon. Kodeeswaran, I will give you one minute so that the Prime Minister can clarify. I am sure what you have to say is also something on this.
( ) (The Hon. Kaveenthiran Kodeeswaran) , 22 . Hon. Deputy Minister P. Ruwan Senarath . , . , .
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) The Hon. Prime Minister.

) ( () () ) (The Hon. (Dr.) (Ms.) Harini Amarasuriya) Hon. Deputy Speaker, once again, let me reiterate the fact that we are determined to see that justice is meted out to this family. In fact, Hon. Member, I felt that the letter Ms. Ahimsa Wickrematunge had sent to me was also extremely measured given the circumstances and what this family has had to endure for the past, I do not know how many years. So, we are very determined because at the end of the day, the purpose of having a judicial system, the Attorney-Generals office, all of these institutions is to deliver justice and if procedures come in the way of delivering justice, then we need to re-examine those procedures. We have taken several actions and are expecting the Attorney-General to take some action today as well. This is something we are closely monitoring. As I said, we are definitely looking into whether we can initiate fresh indictments on this case; we will do

everything within our power. Also, let us not forget that the Attorney-Generals Department and related institutions, even though there are good officers with good intentions, have got used to a particular way of working, have worked within a particular culture. That also needs to change. That takes time, but taking time does not mean that victims can wait forever for answers. So, this is something that is very sensitive, of which we are very aware, and we will do what we can. Hon. Member, we are ready to allocate a full day to debate on this issue because we also agree that this is extremely important.

Thank you for the time given, Hon. Deputy Speaker. ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Next, the Ministerial Statement by the Hon. Vijitha Herath, Minister of Foreign Affairs, Foreign Employment and Tourism.

Hon. Members, I wish to state the modality or how we are going to conduct the Private Members Motions and the allocation of time for the Motions. I wish to inform the Hon. Members of Parliament that the total time allocation for the six Private Members Motions scheduled for today is five and a hours or 330 minutes. However, I would like to remind you all that since we have already started late, there could be some adjustments in the allocation of time.

The time allocated for each Motion is 55 minutes. Once again, that may need to be adjusted as we go on and the breakdown is as follows: for the Mover of the Motion, 10 minutes; for the Seconder of the Motion, five minutes; for all other Members of Parliament taking part in the debate, 25 minutes; for the Minister in charge of the subject to reply, 10 minutes and for the Mover for winding up the Motion, five minutes.

I am just trying to say that the procedure in doing any sort of development in the plantations is extremely complicated. If I, as the subject Minister, want to do anything in the plantations, I need to first request the manager of that plantation. After requesting the manager, I need to go to the PMMD. After the approval of the PMMD, I need the approval of the Ministry of Finance. After their approval, I need to go back to the manager. Then, I need to get the GAs approval and by the time I complete all of this, an entire year goes by, which is why I am telling the Hon. Minister that more than talking about allocating money for these roads or about issues with regard to those roads, you need to address the root of the problem, the procedure itself.

I would just like to end by saying that as far as I am concerned, with this current situation, the people of Indian origin living in this country are not citizens of Sri Lanka, but citizens of the plantation companies because, today, for everything based on their livelihood, they need to get permission from the plantation company. It does not happen anywhere else. Government workers do not get permission from the employers with regard to their livelihood matters. Why is the rule different for us?
( ) (The Hon. Deputy Speaker) Next, the Hon. Chaminda Wijesiri. You have three minutes.

ABOLISHING THE PENSION SCHEME OF THE MEMBERS OF
( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Hon. Presiding Member, I move,

That this Parliament resolves that the Pension Scheme of the Members of Parliament of Sri Lanka should be abolished with immediate effect as it is very apparent that Sri Lankan voters are very hostile for Parliament Members to receive pensions after the completion of their term of office.

Sir, today, I stand up in Parliament to propose and discuss a matter that has been a source of great discontent and frustration among the people - the pension awarded to the Members of Parliament. The pension currently granted to the Members of Parliament is seen by many as an undue privilege granted often to those who had served in Parliament for a brief period; it is seen as deeply unjust, unfair and unreasonable from the peoples perspective. Therefore, it is time to align the benefits enjoyed by the elected Representatives with those of the citizens they serve. We must recognize that public service is a noble calling and one that should be driven by the desire to serve the people and not for personal gain. The pension awarded to the MPs has created the perception that political office is a pathway to personal enrichment rather than a platform for public service. This perception erodes the trust between the electorate and their Representatives. That trust is fundamental to the functioning of democracy. Let us work together to create a political culture where integrity and selflessness are valued above all; let us ensure that our elected Representatives are motivated by a genuine desire to improve the lives of their fellow citizens. Our pension could be better spent on essential services such as healthcare, education and infrastructure, which directly benefit the people of Sri Lanka.

Therefore, Sir, I propose the abolition of the pension scheme for the Members of Parliament. That is for eradication of inequity and as a move of fairness and justice. It is a step towards restoring the faith of the people in Parliamentarians and ensuring that the elected public office remains a commitment to serve the people and not to be served.
: : , , , , :, : : , : : ; if you pay peanuts, you get monkeys.
, let us invest in bringing professionals into Parliament. That is why I am proposing this and I also invite Parliament to give thought to ensuring that we bring in true professionals to Parliament.

Then, in order to ensure that professionals retain here, they should be duly paid in the correct manner without just looking at restricting and reducing one aspect of it only. 227: : , : Salary, Allowances and Pension of Members of Parliament Act of 1954 , , , : : , : :, : , ,

Hon. Prime Minister, now that you are there eagerly listening to me, I would like to say that we must invest for tomorrow. Let us ensure that the younger generation also join in and become part and parcel of this nation-building exercise. We, coming from a professional background as well as from a business environment, may be able to withstand its strain, but, certainly, it is not an easy life. And, I speak on behalf of the many who have been elected to Parliament this time, whose salaries go to a public fund and who is being paid by the party from it. I looked at it and I call upon you all to consider this. Now, you all are basically looking at restraining your expenditure. Even when the President goes to Jaffna - my belief is that the President represents the entire country - why should he waste six hours being on the road when he can go by helicopter? That is what the modern world does. Even to the Hon. Prime Minister, I suggest that. You hold the position of Prime Minister; you are not just Harini Amarasuriya anymore. So, why do you not use that? That is not a loss to the country. The money that you lose by wasting six hours being on the road is a loss to the country. So, I propose that from the Opposition because these are not extravagant expenditure. That is the way to develop countries. I mean, if you are in America and if you want to go from one state to another by road, it will take two to three days. So, use the technology.

Likewise, I say, relook at this pension. I am proposing this owing to the fact that there was such a lot of hysteria and negativity expressed against MPs getting a pension. I want to resurrect the confidence, the command and the respect that people had had for Parliament.
Sir, I would wind up, inviting the Hon. M. Nizam Kariapper to second my Motion.

. ( . ) (The Hon. M. Nizam Kariapper, PC) , , -- - --, . Thank you. This, I have been doing even in the Courts. Okay, I will have to speak quickly because the Chair is going to control me regarding time.

I rise, Hon. Presiding Member, to second this Motion and let me raise one point. I believe the Hon. Karunanayake is proposing to do it prospectively and not retrospectively. If it is done prospectively, some of us and most of you on the Government side, the newcomers, would be the victims and not the past Members. But, be that as it may.

I appreciate what you said, Hon. Prime Minister. I guess taking that first step is the step in the right direction. I have extended my support. So, let us walk together and ensure that we achieve it. I do not think it takes generations to get that change made. If you have the commitment, I guess we can get to the Singapore model. When Lee Kuan Yew came to Sri Lanka, he looked at Sri Lanka as a role model, went back and said, This is what I thought Singapore would be in future. But, later on he said, I do not want to take my country through what Sri Lanka has gone through. So, let us change the model; let Singapore follow us before too long. We extend our support and let us work towards fiscal discipline and, more or less, a proper system. So, instead of blaming the past, let us work together towards the unborn future. Again, I appreciate the support you extended. Let us ensure that we build a new future from this moment itself.
. . Question put, and agreed to. ( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) , 6 ,
APPOINTING A SELECT COMMITTEE OF PARLIAMENT TO
RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING THE CREMATION, INSTEAD OF BURIAL, OF THE

"8. Expresses further concern that the response to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has had an impact on freedom of religion or belief and exacerbated the prevailing marginalization of and discrimination against the Muslim community, and that cremations for those deceased from COVID-19 have prevented Muslims and members of other religions from practising their own burial religious rites, and has disproportionately affected religious minorities and exacerbated distress and tensions;
9. Calls upon the Government of Sri Lanka to ensure the prompt, thorough and impartial investigation and, if warranted, prosecution of all alleged crimes relating to human rights violations..."
Then the Resolution dated 06th October, 2022 adopted by the Human Rights Council states, I quote:

"11. Also urges the Government of Sri Lanka to take measures to address the marginalization of and discrimination against persons from the Muslim community, and to ensure that Muslims and members of other religions are able to continue to practise their own religious rites, including burial rites;

12. Calls upon the Government of Sri Lanka to ensure the prompt, thorough and impartial investigation and, if warranted, prosecution of all alleged crimes relating to human rights violations ... with the full participation of victims and their representatives;"
With this in mind, I have posed a few questions earlier to the Hon. Minister of Health regarding some details I sought.

Be that as it may, may I now go on to point out how many directives and manuals of internationally-recognized institutions had been violated by the Sri Lankan Government at that time. I want to list these documents which are internationally-accepted manuals relating to COVID-19 deaths. Number one is, "Infection, Prevention and Control for the safe management of a dead body in the context of COVID-19: World Health Organization: 24th March, 2020". This interim guidance still stands and has not been revised.

Number two is, Interim Guidance on water, sanitation, hygiene and waste management for the COVID-19 virus dated 19th March, 2020 issued by the WHO and the UNICEF. This Interim Guidance still stands and has not been revised. Number three is, "Statement on COVID 19: Ethical Considerations from a Global Perspective", Statement of the UNESCO International Bioethics Committee and the UNESCO World Commission on the Ethics of Scientific Knowledge and Technology dated 26th March, 2020. This Guidance Statement still stands and has not been revised. Number four is, Recommended Measures for the Safe Burial of Bodies of Deceased Persons with COVID-19- Professional Working Group for the safe burial of bodies of deceased persons with COVID-19 in Sri Lanka. It details the hydrogeological factors in Sri Lanka in relation to disposal of COVID dead and was prepared by a group of Sri Lankan hydrogeologists and environmental engineers who

provide details of safe options for burial in Sri Lanka. Number five is, International Committee of the Red Cross: General Guidance for the management of the dead related to COVID -19 dated 31st March, 2020. This Interim Guidance still stands and has not been revised. Number six is, practical considerations and recommendations for religious leaders and faith-based communities in the context of COVID-19. That Interim Guidance dated 7th April, 2020 was issued by the WHO and has also not been revised.

Sir, the decision taken by the so-called Expert Committee in this country is contrary to all these guidelines which have already been practised in 192 other countries. We are the only country which followed a practice other than what has been directed by these guidelines. So, that is why I am proposing a Select Committee be appointed so that we will be able to go into the facts, as to what led this particular Committee to come to this horrendous decision totally against all the medical ethics.
Then, Sir, I would like to quote from the famous medical journal The Lancet, which talks in its Editorial about "Advancing racial and ethnic equity in health".
Racism is a public health emergency of global concern.

" an acknowledgment of racism and its harms - hatred, intolerance, and discrimination kill. These issues are as pervasive in medicine, medical science, and global health as in society. Today, The Lancet publishes a special issue bringing together the strongest evidence and analysis on advancing racial and ethnic equity in science, medicine, and health

"Racism is not only about the health of particular persecuted or excluded groups - it inflicts a collective trauma on us all. The positive corollary of this fact is that lessening inequities and restoring justice can bring healing to society as a whole."

Since this sort of thing has happened, in order to set the record straight, to expose the culprits who, currently in this administration too, are enjoying responsible positions including the Secretary to the Ministry positions and other important positions and as to why they came to this decision, not a single inquiry has been conducted. So, having flouted all the internationally accepted norms, they have gone on enjoying all the perks of office without any reprimand and disciplinary action. Therefore, a Select Committee must be appointed to look into the facts relating why this decision was reached. Just an apology by the Government alone would not do, Mr. Presiding Member. Therefore, we are urging this House to appoint a Select Committee to go into the evidence and to find out who was responsible for that decision and then, that will address the concerns expressed by the United Nations Human Rights Council as well. Thank you.

, "Water Research" journal article It states, I quote:

The data available suggest that: i) CoV seems to have a low stability in the environment and is very sensitive to oxidants, like chlorine; ii) CoV appears to be inactivated significantly faster in water than non-enveloped human enteric viruses...

So, it has been scientifically accepted and proven in scientific journals. Therefore, how can this particular lady, calling herself a geological expert, come to such a conclusion based on her whims and fancies? So, she has to come and place those facts to justify. That is what we are asking for.
